acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 72-hour ErC50 = 60 mg/L for algae (Pseudokirchneriella subcapitata) (Test for the Ecological Effect of Chemical Substances (Ministry of the Environment), 2001), the substance was classified into Category 3.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on its rabbit LD50 of > 5000 mg/kg (HSDB, 2008), the substance was classified into the "Not classified" category.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Its rat LC50 is 4.6 mg/L/4h (HSDB (2008)), which is greater than its saturated vapour pressure concentration (0.07-0.035 mg/L), indicating that the study was conducted in a mist state. This is the only test result available, and the choice between Category 4 and the "Not classified" category cannot be determined. Thus, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on its rat LD50 of 7000 mg/kg (JECFA No. 906, accessed in November 2008), the substance was classified into the "Not classified" category.

carcinogenicity.rationale: In 18-20-month dermal administration tests using mice, skin cancer was not found (Patty (5th, 2001)). In addition, either a mouse skin-painting study or 80-week skin test did not show any evidence of carcinogenicity (HSDB, 2008). Since information obtained was on one species and of dermal administration tests only, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Its classification for acute toxicity is Category 3, and its 21-day NOEC = 18 mg/L for crustaceans (Daphnia magna) (Test for the Ecological Effect of Chemical Substances (Ministry of the Environment), 2001). Based on these results, the substance was classified into the "Not classified" category.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Since its flash point of 118degC (closed cup) (Sax (11th, 2004)) is >= 93degC, this substance is not a GHS-classified flammable liquid.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: No in vivo test data are available, and only negative results have been obtained from in vitro mutagenicity tests (Ames tests) (NTP Database, accessed in November 2008). Thus, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: The substance contains oxygen (but not fluorine or chlorine) which is chemically bonded only to carbon or hydrogen.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Its autoignition point is 380degC (Sax (11th, 2004)). According to classification guidelines, a substance with its autoignition point >= 70degC falls under the "Not classified" category.

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Teratogenicity tests using rats found no signs of developmental toxicity (Patty 5th, 2001), (HSDB (2008)). In addition, reproduction and developmental studies using female rats found no toxic effects either (HSDB, 2008). However, since effects of the substance on male fertility is not explored, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Since it is found to be a skin corrosive substance (based on rabbit skin irritation test (Patty 5th, 2001)), it was classified into Category 1. There are no eye irritation test results available.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Rabbits were exposed to the substance for 4 hours, and as a result, treated subjects, as a whole, were graded 5.6 on a scale of 1 to 8 of the primary irritation index, indicating that the substance is corrosive (Patty 5th, 2001). Based on these results, the substance was classified into Category 1. It is rated as R34 in the EU classification (equivalent to Category 1B or 1C) (EU-Annex 1, accessed in November 2008).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In 4-week mixed diet tests using rats (dose: 3400 mg/kg, 90-day correction: 1058 mg/kg), the only symptom noted was body weight reduction (Patty (5th, 2001)). Similarly, in 27-day forced oral administration tests (doses: 0, 875, 1750, and 3500 mg/kg), there were no significant findings that could be related to administration of the test substance at 875 and 1750 mg/kg bw/day (90-day correction: 262.5 and 525 mg/kg, respectively) (HSDB (2008)). These results indicate that the substance falls under the "Not classified" category (oral route), but since there are no test results using other administration routes, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category due to insufficient data available. As additional notes, in 2-week dermal administration tests using rabbits (dose: 500 mg/kg, 25% solution), histopathological examinations found unrevealing results (Patty (5th, 2001)). Thus, these results were not used as grounds for classification.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause drowsiness or dizziness (narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: In oral administration tests using rats (1350-15380 mg/kg bw), symptoms such as hypoactivity, salivation, labored breathing, muscular weakness, and prostration were observed in a dose-dependent fashion, although concentrations that induce these symptoms could not be determined (HSDB, 2008). Based on these results, the substance was classified into Category 3 (narcotic effects). In a hypodermic administration test using rabbits (dose: 0.5 ml, specific gravity correction value: 460 mg/kg), the following changes were observed: discolored abdomen, pigment alteration in the lung, liver, spleen and adrenal, dark red foci in the right kidney and inside walls of the stomach, and vascularization of the intestine. However, since it was a single dose test, we did not use these results as grounds for classification.
